author: liqdmetal369
content: a lot of vague terms are being used in here like "healthier", "right price", "ux improvement". however the real crux of the 1559issue is the economic model change favoring deflation instead of hash-rate (security). in effect holders win while nethash and miners lose. either way you still have the tx volume spike problem. i will repeat that to me, 1559 may make sense for eth 2.0 (pos network), but not so much on pow (eth1).

author: pietjepuk
content: Hash rate/security should be incentivized with block rewards, not transaction rewards. If you think that the future level of security with EIP-1559 is not high enough (or even the current level), then you should propose an EIP to increase the block reward and argue your case.

author: liqdmetal369
content: it is a simply function of Supply (fixed and capped due to technical conditions of the network), price (this goes up when tx demand overwhelms tx supply), and demand for tx. at end of day 1559 doesnt do much if anything to my eye. no one had any data when i asked to reveal the problems that 1559 theoretically fixes. things like "miner coalition could" and such were speculated on

author: pietjepuk
content: What? We were talking about security just now, and now we're talking about space on the blockchain.

author: liqdmetal369
content: block rewards have been reduced. i think there is perhaps enough in just the block reward for the miners. but i dont think its a good idea to mess with the economic security model for the supposed 1559 improvements.

author: liqdmetal369
content: the system as is self balances.. excepting the tx demand spike

author: liqdmetal369
content: blocks are basically full now, 1559 does not improve tx throughput

author: pietjepuk
content: it won't make transactions cheaper no, but it doesn't try to do that anyway

author: pietjepuk
content: It tries to make the estimation of the price to pay for precious space on the blockchain easier to estimate/determine (the touted UX benefit), and solve a few of these side-channel payments to miners (iirc, not sure about this one) and miners forking of blocks with high-transaction rewards

author: mmdc
content: if you think 1559 is to improve the tx throughput, you got it wrong

author: liqdmetal369
content: ^ put more words in my mouth

author: liqdmetal369
content: tx throughput is the real problem

author: liqdmetal369
content: has alot to do with pricing though because it is a capped supply

author: liqdmetal369
content: you know supply demand

author: pietjepuk
content: well, tx throughput is definitely _a_ problem

author: pietjepuk
content: but the problem that EIP-1559 is trying to solve is the pricing of said limited supply (whether it's 12.5M gas, or 100 times that)

author: liqdmetal369
content: I understand that, but the primary problem of tx demand spike (and price that follows) is not addressed. the BIG part of 1559 is the burn. stabilizing the tx fee pricing is not going to happen in practice because of the noted throughput problems

author: pietjepuk
content: That's again not something that EIP-1559 tries to solve. If there is a demand spike, all we want to know is what the current going rate for gas is. And first-price auctions are terrible at it, and EIP-1559 is better at it.

author: pietjepuk
content: doesn't mean there won't be demand spikes all of a sudden, of course there will be

author: liqdmetal369
content: exactly, very marginal improvement for a large change to the economic security model

author: pietjepuk
content: you already said yourself earlier that the security is not affected much, so I'm not sure what you're saying now

author: pietjepuk
content: and I wouldn't call good price estimation a marginal improvement for anyone actually using Ethereum for transactions and dApps

author: liqdmetal369
content: i suspect it wont be, but who is to say

author: liqdmetal369
content: marginal because it doesnt address the root problem

author: pietjepuk
content: there is no root problem

author: pietjepuk
content: it's a _different_ problem

author: liqdmetal369
content: you wouldnt be splitting hairs about pricing schema if tx throughput wasnt capped

author: pietjepuk
content: of course you would!

author: liqdmetal369
content: price go up to get your tx through more likely.

author: liqdmetal369
content: in either system

author: pietjepuk
content: storage and computation have costs associated with them, always

author: liqdmetal369
content: burn is the major change, how you dont see that im not sure

author: liqdmetal369
content: less to miners = less hash = less pow network security

author: pietjepuk
content: then propose to increase the block reward!

author: pietjepuk
content: with the average transaction reward over the last year for my part

author: liqdmetal369
content: deflationist hawks run eth foundation based on previous experience

author: liqdmetal369
content: burns and reward reductions

author: liqdmetal369
content: im just saying

author: liqdmetal369
content: this is a marginal improvement if any for large changes to economic model

author: liqdmetal369
content: dont put the cart in front of the horse by pretending otherwise

author: pietjepuk
content: you're making a whole lot of contradictory arguments.. I also feel like you're assuming that the EF (or Ethereum as a whole) is there to reward miners

author: liqdmetal369
content: how much burn is gonna happen when we have a tx demand spike

author: pietjepuk
content: miners will get the minimum reward to secure the network, there is no need to pay them more

author: pietjepuk
content: lots of uncertainty in that estimation of course, so typically on the conservative side

author: liqdmetal369
content: we already condensed it down, you are into moral relativity type discussion

author: liqdmetal369
content: because less rewards to miners = less hash = less security

author: liqdmetal369
content: that is a fact

author: pietjepuk
content: sure, I don't disagree with that

author: pietjepuk
content: that "less security" might still be enough though

author: jgm
content: less issuance = higher ETH price = more hash rate

author: jgm
content: (Just to throw a counter-argument in there)

author: pietjepuk
content: yeh, I've also been wondering about that

author: liqdmetal369
content: yup that is true as well jgm

author: pietjepuk
content: caring about a few ETH more or less being rewarded is _nothing_ compared to the price fluctuations

author: pietjepuk
content: if anything, you should be angry at the price moving up/down

author: liqdmetal369
content: but 1559 reduction in fees is a bigger force that price appreciation due to burn

author: liqdmetal369
content: in my opinion

author: liqdmetal369
content: a burn rewards big capital already holding moreso than active capital running miners

author: pietjepuk
content: that's very speculative

author: liqdmetal369
content: i mean big cap and big miners could be one and same

author: liqdmetal369
content: likely are

author: liqdmetal369
content: but there are lots of little miners

author: pietjepuk
content: so far I haven't seen much correlation between monetary supply and price, but this is waaaay beyond discussion on EIP-1559

author: liqdmetal369
content: ^? when you burn the tx fee how you figure

author: liqdmetal369
content: is that not deflationary force counter to inflationary block reward

author: pietjepuk
content: But why do you care though, why does the exact inflation rate matter if the security of the network is not affected, if the UX is improved, if some attacks are mitigated, and price swings currently are much larger than issuance rate lowering (deflation is unlikely I think, transaction rewards are < 2 ETH most of the time afaik)

author: timbeiko
content: <@!199406759800995840> I suggest you read Tim Roughgarden's analysis of 1559, it does cover a lot of your concerns: http://timroughgarden.org/papers/eip1559.pdf

author: timbeiko
content: All these terms are pretty explicitly defined in the report I linked above. Yes, at the margin, miners lose *some* revenue which is redistributed back to ETH holders. No one has done a great job of quantifying just how much that is, though.

author: justaresearcher.
content: Some revenue? FFS it’s more than just some revenue.

author: timbeiko
content: Well, historically the sum of transaction fees was much lower than block rewards

author: timbeiko
content: Recently, that's been flipped, so if you compare to that, of course the part of revenue lost grows

author: timbeiko
content: But it's worth noting that a lot of cases when fees spike today (e.g. arbitrage, liquidations, etc.) are cases where under 1559 people will probably put very large tips over the base fee.

author: timbeiko
content: So it's unclear what the net loss to miners will be.

author: justaresearcher.
content: The economics of that change are unclear but let’s push it through anyways? Seems like this is as contentious if not more than progpow was. We know how that went for miners

author: pietjepuk
content: as long as payment to miners is enough that security is unaffected, I'm not sure why we should care all that much about it tbh

author: timbeiko
content: The economics are clear: block reward should be sufficient to incentivize miners, as it was for most of the network history.

author: justaresearcher.
content: You just said the net loss to miners was unclear.

author: liqdmetal369
content: im wondering about dag file size effects if any due to increase block size, i am also wondering about extra hd capacity required for storing the blockchain? its clear there is an economic agenda greater than any ux improvement

author: liqdmetal369
content: technical aspects are not as clear to me

author: pietjepuk
content: on average the block size will remain the same

author: liqdmetal369
content: yup so take from miners, give to hodlers is the primacy of this

author: liqdmetal369
content: theoretical better ux better default price schema

author: liqdmetal369
content: can still tip tho, which i actually like

author: pietjepuk
content: Can? It's very much a requirement lol

author: liqdmetal369
content: main problems happen in a high tx and growing tx demand environment

author: liqdmetal369
content: which is not addressed at all, so marginal improvement in real world conditions if any

author: pietjepuk
content: Again, as long as miners are paid enough, that's all we care about.

author: justaresearcher.
content: Which brings me back to my question, why as a miner should I put your transaction into a block if it doesn’t have a tip?

author: pietjepuk
content: not to sound too harsh, but saying things like this makes me thing you haven't read up on EIP-1559 at all

author: justaresearcher.
content: So during normal times where congestion isn’t as much of a factor, why not just mine empty blocks like bitmain has for years?

author: justaresearcher.
content: I’ve read the EIP. I don’t understand the incentive structure for miners

author: justaresearcher.
content: If there’s no tip, why put your transaction into a block?

author: pietjepuk
content: incentive for miners to mine blocks is the block reward, incentive to include transactions is the tip

author: justaresearcher.
content: Wrong

author: pietjepuk
content: correct

author: justaresearcher.
content: We get block reward regardless

author: pietjepuk
content: reeeeaaaad

author: justaresearcher.
content: I did.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners still receive a fee under 1559.

author: justaresearcher.
content: The transaction fees currently are our incentive for putting transactions into blocks. Why would I put a tip less transaction into a block?

author: sky.cactus
content: There is just also another new fee, separate from miner fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: You wouldn't.  Clients will still be programmed to only accept transactions with a sufficiently large (configurable) miner fee.

author: pietjepuk
content: which is probably a gas price of like 1 or 2 Gwei.. but again, this has been covered in e.g. the Q&A with Tim Roughgarden ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ndNyx-Oj9Wk )

author: liqdmetal369
content: fallback to academic theory

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, of course. These are blockchains were talking about, we can't just rely on people being nice. Got to properly incentivize the behavior you want (or disincentivize the behavior you don't want)
